title: How to Use Nettle Leaf

steps.headline: Purchase nettle leaf at a health food store.
steps.description: You can buy dried nettle leaf loose or in tea bags at most health food or vitamin and supplement stores. Look for products that are certified organic. If you purchase nettle leaves online, make sure to buy them from a reputable company that sells organic herbs, such as Mountain Rose Herbs, Frontier Co-op, or Pacific Botanicals. If you live in the U.S., check that the leaves are USDA certified organic.

steps.headline: Weigh and place 1 ounce (28 g) of dried nettle leaf into a large jar.
steps.description: Making an infusion requires a lot of the dried herb, so measure out about 1 cup (240 mL) of the nettle leaf by volume. Pour the herb into a jar that can hold 1 US quart (950 mL) of water. Use a glass jar that has a lid you can seal. Make sure the jar is clean before you use it.

steps.headline: Boil 1 US quart (950 mL) of water.
steps.description: Pour the water into a pot on the stove on high heat. When the water reaches a rolling boil, allow it to boil for 3 minutes to remove any impurities. Then, remove the pot from the heat. Removing impurities from the water will help prevent bacteria from building up in the infusion, making it last longer.

steps.headline: Pour the water into the jar of nettle leaf.
steps.description: Use an oven mitt or a potholder to pick up the pot of water. Carefully add all of the water into the jar containing the nettle leaf. Place the jar into the sink when you pour the water into it in case you spill some of it.

steps.headline: Close the lid of the jar tightly.
steps.description: Once the jar is filled, immediately screw the lid on tightly. The jar needs to be sealed in order for the nettle leaf to properly infuse with the water. Wear an oven mitt when you’re putting the lid on so you don’t burn yourself.Tip: If you don’t have a lid for the jar or container, cover the top with a plate and put something like a book or a glass on it to weigh it down and keep it covered.

steps.headline: Let the nettle leaf steep for up to 10 hours.
steps.description: An infusion aims to extract as much of the vitamins, minerals, and antioxidants from the nettle leaf as possible, so it takes a long time. Generally, 4 hours is long enough for a basic infusion, but the longer you can let it steep, the better! After about 10 hours, the water will have extracted as much as it can and bacteria can start to form in the water.

steps.headline: Strain the nettle leaf and store the jar in the refrigerator.
steps.description: Once the infusion is finished, use a strainer to remove all of the nettle leaf from the water. To keep the infusion lasting longer, keep it stored in your refrigerator. You can drink as much of the infusion as you like, but for the best results, try to consume up to 4 US quarts (3.8 L) a week. You can store the infusion in your refrigerator for up to 4 days.

steps.headline: Place 2 teaspoons (9.9 mL) of dried nettle leaves in a tea strainer.
steps.description: Dried nettle leaves can be really small and crumbly, which can make them difficult to remove when they’re done steeping. Measure out your nettle leaf and use a tea strainer to keep them contained. For a milder tasting tea, use 1  tsp (4.9 mL) of dried nettle leaf.

steps.headline: Put the tea strainer into a glass or mug.
steps.description: Once you’ve measured the nettle leaf and added it to a tea strainer, place it in a glass or mug that you use to make tea. The tea will be hot when it’s finished, so use a glass or mug that you can hold with hot liquid inside of it. If you don’t have a tea strainer, use tea bags, or put the nettle leaf directly into the glass or mug.

steps.headline: Pour 8 fluid ounces (240 mL) of boiling water over the strainer.
steps.description: Use a kettle or a pot on the stove and bring the water to a rolling boil. Then, remove it from the heat and slowly pour the water over the dried nettle leaf.

steps.headline: Steep the nettle leaf for 10-15 minutes.
steps.description: Leave the nettle leaf undisturbed for the first 5 minutes. Then, lift the strainer out of the water every few minutes and let the water run back into the cup. This will help to flush out the vitamins, minerals, and antioxidants in the nettle leaf. If you’re using a tea bag, try to pull it out of the water and let the excess water run back into the glass or mug. For nettle leaf that is free-floating in the water, let it steep for 15 minutes.

steps.headline: Remove the tea strainer.
steps.description: When the nettle leaf is done steeping, take the strainer out of the water and let the excess fluid run back into the cup. Do not try to press or squeeze any fluid out of the nettle leaf or it could add a bitter flavor to the tea. If you used loose nettle leaf to make your tea or there are particles of nettle leaf floating in the water, strain it through a coffee filter or some cheesecloth to remove them.Tip: Add some milk, honey, or fresh lemon juice to enhance the flavor of the tea!

steps.headline: Remove the leaves from the stem.
steps.description: The stems of the nettle leaf are really tough and fibrous. They also have small thorns that can sting and poke you. Use a pair of scissors to cut off the leaves where they connect to the stem. Cut them over a bowl or colander so you can collect them as you remove them. Discard the stems when you’re done with them but be careful not to prick yourself with the thorns.

steps.headline: Rinse the leaves under cool water.
steps.description: Whether you picked the nettle leaf yourself or you purchased some fresh from a grocery store, you need to clean the leaves before you eat them. Run them under cool water and use your fingers to brush off any dirt or debris on them. Remove any thorns you find while you’re washing the leaves. Drain the excess water off of the leaves before you cook them.

steps.headline: Add 1 tablespoon (15 mL) of olive oil to a pan on medium heat.
steps.description: Place a saucepan on the stove and set the temperature to medium heat. Add your oil to the pan and let it heat up for 3-4 minutes. Swirl the oil around the pan to coat the whole surface.Tip: If you don’t have olive oil, you can use butter, or another oil like vegetable, avocado, or coconut.

steps.headline: Place the leaves in the pan and cook them for 5-6 minutes.
steps.description: Keep the heat set to medium and stir the leaves around frequently so they cook evenly. Continue cooking them until all of the leaves are soft. Then, remove them from the pan and serve them while they’re hot. Add a pinch of salt and black pepper to season the leaves.

steps.headline: Eat the leaves or pair them with another dish.
steps.description: Think of the nettle leaf as spinach: you can add it to a dish or you can eat it as a solo side dish. There aren’t any limitations about how you can use it as part of a meal. Add cheese to it and make a tasty side dish or dip. Saute onions and mushrooms and add them to the greens for a heartier dish. Put them in a soup to help reduce any bitterness in the nettle leaf.

steps.headline: Use nettle leaf cream to relieve joint pain and inflammation.
steps.description: Nettle leaf can be applied topically as a cream to help soothe joint pain caused by arthritis and other conditions. Be sure to acquire the cream from a reputable source such as a health store or pharmacy. Check online reviews and customer comments on a nettle leaf cream if you plan to purchase it online. Talk to your doctor before you use nettle leaf cream to make sure it’s safe for you.

steps.headline: Apply the cream to painful joints 2 times a day.
steps.description: To help alleviate joint pain and improve your physical function, use the nettle leaf cream every day. Remove the cap, squeeze out a small amount, and rub it into the skin above the injured joint. If you develop a rash or your pain increases, stop using the cream and contact your doctor. Rub the cream into your skin until it fully absorbs.

steps.headline: Store the cream in a cool, dark place.
steps.description: When you aren’t using the nettle leaf cream, keep it stored away from heat and direct sunlight. The cream works best in a semi-solid state and heat and sunlight can melt or change the texture of it. The cream will also last longer if it’s stored properly. Tip: If applying a cool cream helps relieve your joint point, keep the nettle leaf cream in your refrigerator until you’re ready to use it.
